overview_of_class: Students will learn about psychosis, survey popular research approaches, and design research proposals for hypothetical projects. In this class we will learn about major areas of cognitive, emotive, and behavioral dysfunction in schizophrenia as well as related psychotic disorders. We will also survey the most recent developments in the field of intervention, as well as biomarker development in high-risk and premorbid periods. The course will focus heavily on learning about relevant research methodology including eye tracking, motor assessment, psychophysiology, cognitive assessment, and neuroimaging (other modalities will be examined as time permits). This will involve reading about the methodologies and joining the class on a series of field trips to Northwestern Labs (Evanston and Downtown) that are currently employing these approaches.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will submit written reviews of assigned articles as well as critiques of research modalities. They will present individual research projects to the class, and turn in several graded drafts of what will eventually culminate in a final research proposal (detailing the rationale, design, recruitment plan, and analyses for a hypothetical study).

overview_of_class: This course will give students a basic grounding in the class of statistical techniques known as multilevel modeling (MLM). MLM goes by other names as well, such as hierarchical linear modeling (HLM), mixed models, random coefficient modeling, and random effects models. These techniques have been applied to many different research questions within the biomedical, behavioral, social sciences, and even engineering. We will focus on MLM as it is used in behavioral and social science research, with examples from education and adult development. Specifically, we will discuss in detail two types of multilevel models: clustered-observation or organizational models (e.g., children nested within classrooms) and growth-curve models (e.g., estimation of change with measurements nested within people over months or years). If we have time, we can consider a third: daily experience models (e.g., daily or hourly measurements nested within people over days or weeks). Students will also learn how to use SAS Proc Mixed for conducting MLM analyses. Students are assumed to have taken at least two graduate statistics courses and have a solid understanding of regression analysis.
